content.rendered:
Over the past couple years I’ve talked about CMS from Salesforce. The CMS Connect feature then Native CMS. This post covers the last CMS type currently available, Salesforce CRM CMS. To start off, let’s review the differences.

CMS Connect

CMS Connect lets you connect to outside services, be it with or without authorization. The primary difference with Connect is that it is most commonly used with connecting to outside sources so that data does not need to be replicated and maintained in multiple places.

Native CMS

The Native CMS feature that allows you to make Content records such as Event Document and Image. These CMS records are found within Salesforce under the CMS home tab. In addition, you can create custom CMS Types as well, such as event. Most importantly, one of the big advantages of Native CMS is the fact that your record detail is customizable, as well as individual post spotlights. These records come at a cost and are limited to a few hundred free.

CRM Data as Content in a Collection

CRM CMS is from Salesforce record data and let’s you take any custom and/or standard object into a collection with a beautified view.

Companies often have very rich data in their CRM database that they want to expose on their digital touchpoints. For example, you may have product images you want to show with your product catalog OR contact pics to partners on customer records. With Salesforce CRM CMS, one can easily tap into CRM data (standard and custom objects) and have visual, more appealing displays of data in a list. After all, a picture is worth a 1000 words.

Prerequisites:

  1. To allowlist a CRM/CUSTOM object, the user must have edit access on the object.
  2. For a CRM collection to be rendered on unauthenticated pages, read access must be enabled on the CRM/CUSTOM object in the guest user profile.

Allowlisting CRM objects

Select the Salesforce CRM tab under content management and click Add CRM Connections to choose a CRM object to allowlist so that data can be added into a collection. All Standard objects and Custom objects are supported. Let’s review the steps Capricorn took.

Use cases:

  • Create a more visual list view in your community for current products
  • Display videos
  • Contact list with photos
  • Highlight products being featured
  • Add files linked
  • List view of knowledge articles

Allowlisting standard objects

CRM CMS is found in content, similar to Native CMS. On the other hand, CRM CMS does not have a cost, and uses objects and their records, so to create we need to go to the Content Management area

Once inside the content space, go to salesforce CRM and select “Add CRM Connection”.

This is where you select what you want in your collection. Again CRM CMS is data, records in objects. Select the object you want to use for your collection. You follow the same process for standard and custom objects so no need to learn multiple processes.

Collection on CRM data

Start creating a collection and select “CRM Data” and pick the object that you allowlisted. Choose the global list view, which will have the CRM data. More details about creating global list view can be found here.

Create the Collection

On the next screen, enter the Collection Name followed by the type of Salesforce CRM since that is the data type we are working with.

You select the fields available for CRM CMS by using a list view. To ensure that you have your images and correct text, links, title, make sure the fields are visible to community users and part of the list view.

The collection with CRM data is ready for consumption for building community.

Topics for content

One last thing, to assign topics to CMS you need to check the topic is for content. Ensure you do this under “Topics”

Community Builder

After a CRM CMS collection is created, we are able to add it to our community. Head over to builder and decide – where do I drop each collection? Keep in mind you can not use the Single CMS component with CRM CMS, only the collection component.

Setup a page using the flexible page layout so you have more control. This layout ROCKS!!

CRM CMS collection

Used to show your CRM CMS collections through out your community on any page.

  • Can be used on any type of page, Standard, Object, content,
  • CRM CMS cannot be used on record detail, only via a collection on a detail page
  • Collection Layouts: Has 4 different Collection Layouts: Grid, Carousel, Strip and Slideshow
  • Collection Settings uses are:
    • Button configuration for the whole component
    • Number of Columns Displayed
    • Number of Rows Displayed
    • Title Location, If using a title above the component, what will the title be?
  • Content Layout: Has 3 different Content Layouts: Banner, Title, Card
    • The assignment of fields to the component fields, either from the CMS Record of the Salesforce Object record
  • Select your layout then, select the fields to map within the CMS Collection component. You won’t map every field every time, only use the fields you need. Also, you may have you mix and match how you map, due to how fields display.

TIP: one thing to remember is that you can always change where your link goes on your component, just in case you want to download a file field vs going directly to the record.

Summary

Then Tada! You have a collection from data that directs to the record detail page of the record. Some major wins for CRM CMS are:

  • It’s Salesforce records, custom and standard making data more beautiful
  • Gives you a prettier list view
  • Works great with the record detail component from Salesforce labs to fill in page beautification.
  • Unlike Native CMS it’s free no matter the records!
  • Native CMS
  • July 29, 2021
  • In "AwesomeAdmin"
  • CMS Connect for WordPress
  • January 25, 2018
  • In "AwesomeAdmin"
  • CMS Connect 18 Updates
  • June 21, 2018
  • In "AwesomeAdmin"

excerpt.rendered: We’ve talked CMS Connect, Native CMS, now hear all about Salesforce CRM CMS and the wins you get using it in your community!

jetpack-related-posts.title: Native CMS
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Out of the box you you have 3 types of CMS, native CMS is one of those 3. Learn all about it from how to create articles, use cases, and why use Native CMS.

jetpack-related-posts.title: CMS Connect for WordPress
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: So you want to connect your WordPress site to your Community? Here's how it's done with CMS Connect.

jetpack-related-posts.title: CMS Connect 18 Updates
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: My experience at Connections 18 and updates to CMS Connect for your Lightning Community, learn all about it here!

jetpack-related-posts.title: Dreamforce 18 – The Thursday of Presentations
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: This Dreamforce was c-razy!! Not only was it my first Dreamforce as an MVP, but it was also the Dreamforce of back to back action for me. Here's a bit about my #DF18 adventure...

jetpack-related-posts.title: TLS 1.0 Disablement & You
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: TLS 1.0 has been disabled in this organization. Please use TLS 1.1 or higher when connecting to Salesforce using https If you are seeing this error, take a deep breath. There is no need to panic, this is not a showstopper.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Salesforce #OhanaSlack
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Salesforce #OhanaSlack is a Slack Workspace that's available to connect with theSalesforce community and get real time help 24/7.
